commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Wow! This park is huge!

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: I could really use a nap.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: *Sigh*

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: Hey, what's wrong, Emma? You don't seem to have any energy today.

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: Everyone's been giving their all at practice lately, so maybe she's just fatigued.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Maybe we should wrap it up for today. There's still time before the event, so there's no need to rush, Emma.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Oh, sorry, sorry. It's not because I'm tired. There's just something I'm worried about.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Worried? I'm here for you if you want to talk about it.

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: I wanna hear about it too! And so do you, right Shizuku?

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: Of course! You can tell us anything, Emma!

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: I-It's not that big of a deal. Actually, I'm embarrassed to tell anyone since it's so minor.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: The thing is, I'm not sure what kind of school idol I want to be anymore.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: What do you mean by what kind of school idol? I think you should just be yourself, Emma.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: I'm not sure I know what that means anymore. I've started wondering what exactly it is that makes me, me.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: (Worrying about it in the club room wasn't going to help, so to take a break and help Emma understand what makes her unique, I brought her someplace green, like her hometown.)

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: I didn't realize there was such a big park in the city.

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: Oh, wow. You can even set up camp or have a barbecue. I'll have to bring Haruka here sometime!

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: (Everyone looks like they're having fun. I'm glad I decided to bring them here.)

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: *Sigh* Wide, open spaces like this remind me of my hometown. The ranch I grew up on was really spacious, too.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: A ranch? So were there cows and stuff?

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: We had a lot of sheep and goats. All of us kids were carefree, so we would play by singing and dancing for the animals while we pretended we were school idols.

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: That sounds just like you.

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: Totally!

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Ahaha. You think so?

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: All right, let's enjoy every minute of this beautiful day! It looks like there's even a bird-watching area over there.

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: I hear them, but I don't see anything.

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: Hmm. Bird-watching can be quite difficult. Maybe we need binoculars.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Oh, I see one! On that top-right tree, it's a great spotted woodpecker!

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: A great spotted what?

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: You can identify them by the red patch near their tail.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Oh, and there's a blue-and-white flycatcher! I've never seen one in person before! It's so pretty.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Wow, you know a lot about birds, Emma.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: I used to read illustrated reference books for kids to help me learn Japanese.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: It's nice being back among nature, though. I feel so relaxed here. Oh, see this wildflower? I used to eat these a lot back in Switzerland.

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: Henbit? Isn't this that flower that you can suck the nectar out of?

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: In Switzerland, we'd cook it with potatoes and make a really delicious soup. Now I'm starting to get hungry!

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Oh, should we eat lunch then?

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: Yay! Lunch time!

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: Mm-mmm. What is it about eating food outside that makes it taste so much better?

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: It's so true! And it's a beautiful day, too. Everything's perfect!

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Feel free to have some of these sandwiches. I made them using the cheese my family sent me. It's homemade!

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: They make their own cheese?! That's amazing!

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: A lot of people back home do. I made cheese and honey sandwiches with black pepper sprinkled on the cheese. It's really scrumptious.

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: It's certainly a very tasty combination! The saltiness of the cheese combined with the sweetness of the honey is out of this world!

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: I promise to visit Switzerland when I'm all grown up!

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Maybe you can even perform in Europe as school idols someday.

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: What?! That's pretty ambitious of you.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: But wouldn't it be great if we really made it there? Maybe my family could even come watch me.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Stages are nice and all, but it'd be fun to sing in a wide-open place like this under the sun!

commands.speaker: Shizuku
commands.line: Emma, you look much more relaxed now. I'm so glad!

commands.speaker: Kanata
commands.line: Our old, cheerful Emma is back! Believe it or not, I was really worried about you.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: K-Kanata! Shizuku! Thank you! I love you both! Hugs, hugs!

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Did you learn anything that'll help you work through your worries?

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Hmm. I'm not sure yet, but I'm definitely feeling better.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: I'm still not sure what it is that makes me unique, but I do like to be carefree. I think knowing that is enough for now.

commands.speaker: Emma
commands.line: Ahh, I'm really in the mood to sing now!

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Right after saying that, Emma burst into song, and many children gathered around her.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: They surrounded Emma with the most radiant faces.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: Maybe this is the kind of person Emma is?

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: She's a natural, down-to-earth girl who can admit she wants to be carefree. Children accept her because they can see she's genuine. She soothes them, and me, too.

commands.speaker: [player]
commands.line: But I'll tell her all of that after the picnic.
